@graph.title: The price of thirst : global water inequality and the coming chaos
abstract: "There''s Money in Thirst," reads a headline in the New York Times. The CEO of Nestlé, purveyor of bottled water, heartily agrees. It is important to give water a market value, he says in a promotional video, so "we''re all aware that it has a price." But for those who have no access to clean water, a fifth of the world''s population, the price is thirst. This is the frightening landscape that Karen Piper conducts us through in The Price of Thirst-one where thirst is political, drought is a business opportunity, and more and more of our most necessary natural resource is controlled by multinat
